It being period not exceeding 15 minutes and the debateThursday, 19 September 1996 MAIN COMMITTEE 4803 Thursday, 19 September 1996 Second Reading Debate resumed from 18 September, on motion by Mr Costello: That the bill be now read a second time. upon which Mr Gareth Evans moved by way of amendment: That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words: "whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House notes that: (1) the Budget betrays the Australian promise of working towards a more fair, just, inclusive and united society; (2) the Budget is both mindless and heartless, and its prescriptions are not what the Australian economy needs at present; (3) the Budget will have a savagely contractionary impact on economic growth and make impossible the job creation necessary to reduce Australia's still unacceptably high level of unemployment; (4) with stronger economic growth the Budget could be restored to underlying balance over the life of this Parliament through a much more moderate program of fiscal consolidation; (5) the spending cuts and tax increases contained in the Budget are, on the evidence of the Government's own Budget Papers, not necessary to reduce the Commonwealth Government's debt-to-GDP ratio and will not produce a significant improvement in the current account deficit; (6) the Budget not only offers no hope to the unemployed but actively harms their prospects of finding a job by cutting labour market programs and privatising the previously publicly provided employment service function of the CES; (7) the Budget will have unfair and unjust consequences for the struggling and disadvantaged in our midst-the poor, the old, the sick, indigenous Australians and newly-arrived migrants; (8) the many spending cuts concerned with education and training, research and development, trade development (including breaches of promise with respect to EMDG, ITES and lAMP), production bounties, and other business support, will be counter-productive in their longer term consequences; (9) there is deception involved in the family tax package contained in the Budget, whereby what the Prime Minister appears to be putting into one pocket is for most middle Australian families being taken right out of the other by the Treasurer in higher education fees, Austudy changes, higher nursing home charges, higher fees and charges; (10) there are many breaches of Coalition election promises contained in this Budget, which amount to over $17 billion over four years, and which will cause hardship, insecurity, and dismay for millions of Australians; (11) the Budget involves a massive betrayal of regional Australia through the abolition of the $150 million regional development program, large cuts to road funding, the closure of regional Government offices such as Medicare and CES offices, and the cuts to the ABC and university funding; (12) the mean-spirited decision to introduce large, up-front entry fees and massively increased daily fees for nursing homes, and increase user-charges will harm elderly Australians; (13) the abolition of Childcare Operational Subsidies will impact heavily upon community based child care centres;

theText: Since 20 August, when we had the budget handedThursday, 19 September 1996 MAIN COMMITTEE 4805 in tax cuts but Australians were subjected to $13.4 billion in new taxes. When the 1993-94 budget was brought down, some of the highlights were: an increase in wholesale sales tax by two per cent, from 20 to 22 per cent, obviously impacting directly upon many Australian families and many of the goods that they purchase; an increase in petrol tax of 7c and 5c on leaded and unleaded petrol respectively, another major impost on average Australian families; an increase in the excise on tobacco of 15 per cent; the taxation as normal income of lump sum payments for unused annual leave and long service leave; the imposition of FBT on salary package benefits such as membership of social clubs; a tightening of the safety net for the pharmaceutical benefits scheme-and haven't we heard a lot about that in this session of the parliament; restricted access to Medicare benefits for optometry services; a reduction in the growth of defence spending; and the pushing of the pension age for women to 65 over a 20year period. The 1993-94 budget changed Austudy and changed HECS repayments to commence earlier and at higher rates. Yet Labor complains when we make similar changes to HECS in a responsible budget. Labor realigned HECS with income tax arrangements, so payments reflected the proportion of the year for which those with HECS obligations earned above the repayment threshold. That was in 1994-95. It increased departure tax to $27 and increased recovery costs of aviation safety standards. In 1995-96 Labor increased the Medicare levy. It increased the tax on motor vehicles by six per cent, taking it to 22 per cent; increased company tax by three per cent, to 36 per cent; increased the tobacco tax once again by 10 per cent; increased PAYE tax payments; and increased thresholds for the pharmaceutical benefit schemes. The I-a-w tax cuts were never delivered. here is that, whether we are talking about HECS, pharmaceuticals or aged care, whatever we are talking about, the 1993-94, 1994-95 and 1995-96 Keating budgets attacked many of these areas. Labor increased taxes, it increased the burden, and yet the opposition stands up in this parliament and derides this government for the position that it takes. The big difference is this: I would have had no problem with the raising of taxes that Labor undertook if it had been going to result in some improvement to the Australian overall economy. But it did not do that. The previous government simply spent more money. When you spend more money, at the end of the day you do not improve Australia's fiscal position, you do not improve the outlook for the generations to come. Under Labor, family household debt rose to over $200 million, or the equivalent of nearly 70 per cent of household disposable income. That very clearly spells out the rubbish that we have heard in this place in the last few weeks. The difference is that yes, this government is making cuts, that yes, this government is taking a more responsible attitude towards the debt that was imposed upon it by the previous government, but we are going to benefit from it. We are benefiting from it already. Let us look at what has happened since this government came to power. We have had two reductions in home mortgage interest rates of approximately 0.5 per cent which have impacted on families. The people who are benefiting are the people out there who are trying to keep a roof over their heads. Housing is becoming more affordable. before the budget because you could already see the fiscal position that was being set up. throughout Australia. We have also seen a reduction of one per cent in Australia's long-term rates. But, most importantly, the risk factor that Australia pays, the premium we pay for having had such a disgraceful economic management record over the last 13 years, has been reduced since this government has been in power because of the budget measures that were brought down on 20 August by the Treasurer, Mr Costello. We now have a premium of a 1.2 per cent risk factor as opposed to a 2.2 per cent risk factor that we were paying. This effectively means cheaper money for Australian businesses and Australian families. It means that we are no longer going to be connected, because of our foreign debt, by an umbilical cord to overseas companies. I would also like to speak about the other legacy of this mismanagement and that is how we sold off the Australian farm. I welcomed the Prime Minister's initiative last week with the supermarket to Asia but the reality of the situation is we now own only 20 per cent of our food production in this nation, a nation which has a great record for having one of the most efficient farming sectors in the world. In 1989 there was $52.9 billion of foreign ownership in Australia. Foreign investment is not a bad thing, but in 1989 it was $52.9 billion. In 1996, some seven years later, that figure has now reached $190.1 billion of foreign ownership. What have we lost in that time? We have lost an enormous number of national icons and they are things which mean a lot to Australian families. We say, 'Let's buy Australian', but when people tum up to the shops and the kids want a packet of lollies they go and get a packet of Lifesavers. What better Australian icon could you have?

theText: The Iced Vo-Vos are gone!Thursday, 19 September 1996 MAIN COMMITTEE 4807 gone. If you go to the beach the Speedos have gone as well. If an Australian goes to the pub to have an Australian beer he cannot choose Tooheys, he cannot choose XXXX, and he cannot have a Swan because they are all owned by New Zealand. When he pulls on his Stubbies in a morning, or his King Gees, he is not pulling on Australian brand names any more because these companies are owned by the USA. Of course, like myself, a good Australian worker likes to have a Bundaberg rum. There is no point in having that if you are going to support Australian owned products because it is owned by the UK. We all remember when we used to have the Sidchrome super test cricket team and we would have the commentators speaking long and hard about who was going to make it. The Sidchrome super test team really should be a USA team these days because it is no longer an Australian company; it is owned by the USA. The Fairfax media group is partially owned by Canada, as is the TEN network. Yates Seeds is also foreign owned. As for Qantas, you cannot fly in and out of the country without putting money into foreign ownership. The Brashs retail group is another. You cannot buy anything Australian owned these days. Solahart is another. What about Aeroplane Jelly? There was nothing more Australian than Aeroplane Jelly and now it has gone too. Of course, for people in the bush, the Liberal Party is a party that recognises regional and rural Australia. The Liberal Party does represent the bush. We have more members in the bush than any other party. In fact, the Labor Party has only two members in this parliament representing regional Australia. The bottom line is that when bush people go out there to protect themselves on the wild, open plains of Australia and they put on the Akubra hat and their Drizabones, hey, they are supporting overseas industries as well. That is the legacy of our Labor opposition. As the headline said on Saturday, 13 July, in the Sydney Morning Herald, we are fiddling while the farm is being sold off to foreigners. Only 20 per cent of our food assets are now remaining in Australian ownership. I would like to read a quote from that particular article in the Sydney Morning Herald. It says: Fundamentally, the problem is Australians can't, or won't, save and governments don't do much to help them save. Well, this budget that was brought down on 20 August shows exactly what savings can be achieved. It is bringing the budget into balance in three years. I might add, that is exactly what the shadow Treasurer, Mr Gareth Evans, has said should happen. He said three years is a responsible way of going about it. Certainly, there has been hardship but Australians have accepted that this needs to happen. You could say that the Liberal Party and the National Party have brought down a responsible and a caring budget for the future. Before concluding I would like to make one other point regarding the budget and it concerns something which is going to impact very directly on the people of Longman. I am referring to the change from Medicare offices to local agencies. Opposition members like to tell half the story. They are very good at that; they do not seem to be able to tell the full story. Eighty offices are going to be closed. You would say that that is an appalling thing to happen but the reality of the situation is that the closing of 80 Medicare offices means that we are going to be able to open 400 Medicare agencies in regional areas and in outer suburbs such as in Narangba in my electorate.

But I want to return to inflation, because you pay a price when you abandon an employment target. You pay a price-and the price is that if you crunch down on inflation, as this government wants to, you are going to see unemployment increase. The budget papers talk about unemployment rising through the year to 8.5 per cent. You would know, Mr Deputy Speaker, that that figure has already been exceeded. I think you can guarantee one thing about this budget: the growth target will not be met and the unemployment target will be exceeded. That is a tragedy for ordinary Australians, because even if you are in a job you will know people who do not have one or know the despair of not being able to find a job. On the Labor side, we always felt you needed to put people first, that the best form of economy is a strong economy and sustained growth. I would like to see growth even greater than we were able to achieve under the most difficult circumstances. I just want to put that on the record. Not that this is a budget reflecting a charter of budget honesty, but, 'Look how deep, how deceptive, this government has been in burying all the many nasties in it.' No honesty, no openness, no transparency, but guile, deceit and deliberately not living up to the commitments they made to the people of Australia. One day they will be brought to account, let me say. We all get brought to account one day. But in a budget speech of so many nasties it is always difficult to identify the thing that upsets you the most, the thing that you find most objectionable. I think what they are doing about unemployment is really objectionable, and I know it affects a lot of my constituents. Unemployment has been consistently a concern of many of my constituents. But I am going to nominate the thing that I find most abhorrent. Perhaps the member for Fisher is not like me, but I say in my electorate the thing that gives me most pleasure is actually going to school kids, meeting with them and answering questions and speaking to themto be Australian; I am very proud of our country. The children are going to be our future and they are to be nurtured and treated and valued and encouraged. But our senior citizens are the people that have already made their contribution, doing so before my generation. They have done something to develop and make Australia the country it is. It is not that they are not intrinsically nice people; they are. They are lovely and courteous; they give me great support. But they have made a contribution to Australia which I am always happy to acknowledge in terms of what they are leaving me and others. That is why I find what the government is doing about nursing homes so outrageous. What they are doing is insisting on a pre-payment, a down payment on death, by senior citizens in their new nursing home arrangements. The member for Fisher says, 'Oh, that is what you did with hostels.' They are not medically assessed for getting into a hostel, as the member for Fisher well knows. It is a matter of choice whether you live in your home, live in your flat, live with your folks or go into hostel accommodation. With nursing homes there is a medical assessment-an ACAT team. You have to be medically qualified to get into a nursing home. There is no choice in your medical condition; it is a function of the condition that you are in. Mr Slipper interjectingThat is the first lie that has been propounded that I want to nail. There is no choice for people who go into nursing homes. speaker: Mr Price
theText: You are obviously in favour of a down payment on death for senior citizens.Thursday, 19 September 1996 MAIN COMMI1TEE 4811 millionaire, the people you like to represent-buy your way into anything-or whether it is a pauper; whether you are living in a housing department flat in my electorate or your electorate, Mr Deputy Speaker, once you are medically assessed you are into that nursing home bed on a first come, first served basis. The government is going to raise $130 million out of this down payment on death by senior citizens. The minister says, 'It is not up to us. Nursing homes are going to make the assessment about whether they are going to charge $26,000' -and I believe it is going to be closer to $50,000. The minister says that it is not up to the government; it is up to the nursing homes. It may be the case that some of the religious nursing homes are going to take a very compassionate view of it. Under the funding for hostels, they have to set aside a certain percentage for people who cannot pay an up-front fee. But this is not the case with this new nursing home imposition. It is going to be left to the people who run it. Can we say to this government, which is obsessed with bottom lines, profits and private enterprise, that the wealthy Australians who are so well connected to it and who own and operate private nursing homes are suddenly going to say, 'If it is a choice between collecting $26,000 or $30,000'-or whatever the figure that the minister cannot provide is, which we know is at least $26,000-'or not we don't want your money, madam. We are going to freely elect to drop our bottom line. We are not really operating under the profit motive, even though we may be listed or incorporated as a company. We are going to choose some poor person who cannot afford it'? The honourable member for Fisher knows that that is absolute rubbish. The government is doing a number of things to poor, elderly, frail, vulnerable Australians. Firstly, it is saying that if they cannot afford the $26,000 they cannot get into a nursing home, even though they are in a housing commission flat and are medically assessed as requiring a nursing home bed. So their quality of life is going to suffer. When you are medically assessed as requiring nursing home accommodation, you require it. So your quality of life, your medical condition, is going to suffer. This is the destiny for poor, elderly, frail Australians. This is the government's vision of the future. What if they are living at home? What if a family has been concerned enough to have their mother, father or grandparent living at home with them and the elderly person is assessed as requiring nursing home accommodation? What happens in the situation where the family cannot afford the up-front payment on death? What will happen is that there will be an increasing incidence of parents being bashed by their children. That is what is going to happen. I know a lot of senior citizens who are on a pension and are living in their homes. The government says, 'No-one is going to be forced to sell their home.' I will give you an example. This is a true story. There is a couple in my electorate and the husband required heart surgery. They were referred to a cardiologist. They owned some acreage, but were pensioners. They are lovely people. The cardiologist said to them, 'Why do you need to live in your home? Why don't you sell this home and land and pay for the operation?' That is the double jeopardy you are going to be putting people in. What happens where there is a surviving spouse? I will give you another instance, just quoted to me recently, where a wife had been desperate to keep her husband at home. He really needed to go to a nursing home, but she battled to keep him at home. She has had a complete mental breakdown. She is now away from the home being treated. This is the rosy future that the government is painting for elderly, frail Australians, whom it does not value at all. 4812 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 19 September 1996 Getting back to the pensioner in the house receiving a pension: what happens when one of them requires nursing home treatment? What happens when one spouse is convinced that the only way they can get them into the nursing home is by paying the up-front fee? I am afraid to say, pensioners do these things. If they sell the house, probably they will not have their pension affected by the assets test, but they will be deemed on proceeds of the sale of gains. Where does that person live in the meantime? Perhaps, there is an argument that we need to inject $130 million into nursing homes. That is, in a sense, a different argument. But not one cent of this $130 million is going to provide one extra nursing home bed. Not one. You are going to increase the profits of private nursing home owners and operators. I do not say that about the religious and community ones. You are going to increase their bottom line as a dirty election deal. I think what you are doing about nursing homes is absolutely shameful. To suggest, as has been suggested, that it is the same as you are doing for hostels is nothing more than a deliberate, dirty untruth. reasons? are demented? home treatment. I cannot volunteer to go into a nursing home. My mother cannot volunteer to go into a nursing home. My father, I regret to say, or thankfully, is already in a nursing home. But people cannot volunteer their grandparents or their mothers to go in. They have to be medically assessed. I know that the honourable member for Fisher is thick, but I wish he would cotton on to this point. I think that probably, once he fully understands the policy, having got out amongst his senior citizens for whom he has interjected and for whom he has so much admiration, he is going to be embarrassed and, I hope, humiliated. I hope he will be motivated to want to change. I think that this is horrific-absolutely bloody horrific. not add one nursing home bed in Australia! Old people do not want to be a burden on their families. Their one desire in life is to see out their remaining years with dignity and not put any financial burdens on anyone. You have put a new financial terror into this nursing home proposition. Much as the honourable member may interject, it only demonstrates, I think, that even he with his thick hide may be a little bit discomforted by these new arrangements. I say to my senior citizens that I value them. (Time expired) thing to do is to get into perspective the background to the budget. Three dreadful decisions have been made in this country. One of them was the abolition and, it must be added, the undermining of the reserve price scheme for wool in this country. One tenth of this nation's entire export earnings throughout its history has come from wool. In 1988, one-tenth of this nation's export earnings came from a single commodity, wool. speaker: Mr Katter (Kennedy) (L0.43 A.m.)
theText: In saying a few words today, I think that the firstThursday, 19 September 1996 MAIN COMMITTEE 4813 government did. The net result of it was that when the economic rationalists took us into the paradise of enlightenment that we are now in the world's wool buyers were able to buy our wool for $3,000 million a year, instead of $6,000 million a year. On behalf of the world's wool buyers and wool traders, I would like to say thank you to the Australian people for selling a product at around half of its cost of production to us for the last six years. The people that enabled them to do that were the economic rationalists, the people who are the architects of the misery in this country, and they are still riding high in all parts of government. I will move on. The second decision was to deregulate the banking sector. Let me go to no lesser authority than Trevor Sykes and his book The Bold Riders. He designates that, in four short years, there was a loss of $28,000 million. In that book-that brilliant tour de force, giving an understanding of what happened in the 1980s in Australia-Trevor Sykes delineated the cause of the loss of that $28,000 million. That is a lot of money. That is costing this country, to this day, $3,000 million a year. So there were two decisions which cost this country $6,000 million a year. The third decision-for which we must thank, as with all three of these decisions, our economic rationalist friends-was the deregulation of the oil industry. As one person put it to me yesterday, it is like the invisible suit of clothes in this place. Outsiders with any sense say, 'What is going on here? This economic rationalism is madness.' We deregulated 90 per cent of the oil industry in this country. Having proved how successful it was, now we are going to deregulate the other 10 per cent of it. That will indicate the enlightenment that we have in this place. Since the time we deregulated it, the world's price for oil has dropped clean in half, from $34 a barrel down to about $17 or $18 a barrel. But in Australia the price paid to the oil companies in the same period of time doubled. People say to me, 'That is ridiculous. Where did you get those figures from?' I thought everyone knew that the world price of oil had dropped clean in half. But, of course, they think it is all taxation. When they go and fill up at the bowser they know that the price they pay has far more than doubled but they think that it is all taxation. Whilst a lot of it is taxation, the fact is that the price paid to the oil companies rose from 12V2 cents a litre to 22 cents a litre in that same period of time. So, while the world price dropped almost clean in half, the Australian price doubled. That means that the oil companies are taking from the people of Australia $6,000 million a year that they are not entitled to--they are not entitled to one cent of that-because of the slackness in our anti monopolistic legislation and our lack of determination to enforce that legislation in this country. If you take all the taxes off here, we are looking at something around 36 cents a litre. In the United States, the last time. I looked, it was 26 cents a litre. They have adequate antimonopoly legislation which they enforce. That is the background to this budget. If you doubt the extent of the damage that economic rationalists have done to this country, I will quote you some figures. Let us look at average weekly earnings in this country over the last 13 years, under the great hammer of economic rationalism, Mr Keating. I do not doubt for a moment that he has many enthusiastic supporters on our side of the House, so I am not going to stand here and be hypocritical enough to say that it is not the same on our side of the House. These people just seem to keep going with policies without ever assessing whether they work or not. 4814 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 19 September 1996 If you get my speeches from the state parliament, you will find that I was a very strong economic rationalist 15 years ago. You will get a lot of speeches along these lines from me. But I kept watching the figures. I had to say to myself, This policy is not working.' I then had to put my tail between my legs and run, because I was monitoring what was happening out there and what were the results of these decisions. The results of these decisions were absolutely disastrous for this country-the three costing $12,000 million a year. As for average weekly earnings, let me quote the figures and be very specific. In 1983, 61.6 was the CPI index. In 1995, it was 117.6. There was a rise in the CPI of 56 per cent between 1983 and 1995. Average weekly earnings in the same period rose from $341 to $654 and that gave us a rise in average weekly earnings of 47.9 per cent. So average weekly earnings trailed the cost of living by 8.1 per cent. Every person who was on an income in this country was down 8.1 per cent. But that was only a small part of the story. Federal, state and local taxes rose from $52,000 million per year to $151,000 million per year in the same period. Since one-third of all our income goes on taxes, that translates into a reduction of 17.7 per cent in take-home pay for the average wage-earner. The average wage-earner in Australia has suffered a loss in his purchasing power of 26 per cent in the last 13 years under these policies. We now have the highest juvenile suicide rate in the world. Very sadly for me, my electorate is outside the metropolitan area. The suicide rate outside the metropolitan area is six times higher than that in the metropolitan area. I do not have to tell this House of the sea of human misery that exists outside of this place; yet the policies that have created this sea of human misery are continuing unabated. On both sides of the House, there are people who are still out there advocating and implementing these policies. It is deeply regrettable that these people have, like the Bourbons, forgotten nothing and learnt nothing. We have, this year, the highest bankruptcy rates in Australian history. The figures for the past three quarters have all been over 4,000. Let me be very specific. In the past three quarters, there were 12,493 bankruptcies. The March quarter, which is the last quarter for which we have got figures, had the worse figures in Australia's history. On present trends, the final quarter almost certainly will go over the 16,780 bankruptcies of three years ago. It is the worse year for Australian business in Australian history. That is what we have come to, after 13 or 14 years of economic rationalism. Average weekly earnings are down 26 per cent. As far as unemployment goes, add to the other unemployment figures the figures for the part-time unemployed-because, as we all know, if you work for an hour per week, you are registered as employed, not unemployedtogether with the labour market program figures, which the current minister said were over 200,000 but which, on my figures, were most certainly 198,000, and, on top of that, the CDEP figures, which are another 26,000. When you add the three figures together-for the labour market program people, the people who cannot get a full-time job, and the people employed part-time for an hour per week-you come up with a figure, according to Minister Kemp, of 17 per cent. If you would like to go to the past chairman of the Labor economics caucus committee, John Langmore, he says it is 16.5 per cent. Dr John QUiggin, who won the Academy of Science prize in the year before last, quotes the figure as being between 16.5 and 17.5 per cent. I think that we can reasonably assume that the real unemployment rate in this country is 17 per cent. Thursday, 19 September 1996 MAIN COMMITTEE 4815 During the Great Depression, there were only about four years in which unemployment was over 17 per cent. In the United States, it was only over 17 per cent for three years. Whilst we do not have the human pain that was inflicted during the Great Depression-because we have, some might say, adequate unemployment benefits-the human misery that is entailed in not having a job is communicated through the suicide rates in this country. That is where we can find out what it means in this country to have no job and no hope for the future. Let me compare, for those who laud economic rationalism in this country. The very antithesis of economic rationalism was John McEwen. A lot of people say that he and Menzies got their own way all the time. Most certainly, he was the driving force as far as economics went, and he was roundly criticised for his policies. Let us look at the score card in the last year of John McEwen policies. Mr Deputy Speaker, you will have to bear with me, because I am going to compare these figures with the 1991 figures, and most of these figures are worse now than they were in 1991, of course. Unemployment in 1972 stood at 1.9 per cent; in 1991, at 10.5 per cent. The balance of payments in 1972 showed a $754 million surplus. The current account was in surplus. In 1991, there was a $16,000 million deficit. In 1972 there were 2,648 bankruptcies and, in 1991, there were 13,091. In 1972, the value of the Australian dollar was such that it took a whopping great $US 1.28 to buy an Australian dollar. In 1991, the value of the Australian dollar was $USO.76, or ¥384; and it is now ¥95. In 1972, interest rates stood at 7.7 per cent and, in 1991, at 15.5 per cent. In 1972, taxation was at $8.9 billion and, in 1991, $97.9 billion. The interest paid on foreign debt in 1972 was $425 million. The interest paid on foreign debt in 1991 was $19,000 million. Which were the successful policies? They say the world has changed. If we take the phrases used by the current economic rationalists and the phrases used by the people attacking Ted Theodore during the Great Depression, I hate to tell you, Mr Deputy Speaker, but it is the same phraseology, the same turn of phrase-the same words are even being used. How do we get out of the hole that we are in at the present moment? Believe me, we are in a depression. The only reason we do not know that is because we now pay adequate social security payments, which we did not pay during the 1930s. How do we get out of that hole? In fairness to the Treasurer ( Mr Costello) and to the government, it is very hard to keep borrowing money. Three years ago, the interest paid by the federal government was $3,880 million. The interest paid in 1996 was $9,390 million. If the interest bill keeps exploding at that rate, all of our taxation in a 10-year time frame most certainly will go to paying interest just on the federal government's debt. We cannot keep borrowing money, but cutting back on government spending in a recession is not what should be done. That is the very last thing that we should do. The message from what happened in the 1930s was that, when the economy is in recession, cutting back on government spending is the most disastrous move that can be made. So how do we solve this conundrum? To break the cycle, we have to look at adequate antimonopoly laws. We must look at giving our commodity producers, be they wool producers or copper producers or whatever, the ability to collectively market their product. Unless they can collectively market their product, then the little sheep cocky outside of Longreach is being pitted against the might of Itoh of Japan, one of the biggest trading houses in the world. The little sheep cocky outside of Richmond or Julia Creek or Longreach is going to go under, and he is going under at the present moment. The Australian people are going down 4816 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 19 September 1996 as well, because half of our sheep herd-this nation's greatest asset-has already gone. So we must give our commodity producers the right to collectively and aggressively market their product, instead of, as we have been doing in this place, removing that right. That is what we did when we abolished the minimum price scheme in wool. There are many other examples I could use. Three thousand million dollars a year is the benefit in wool alone. Another example is the tobacco industry. A lot of people think that it is collapsing because people are stopping smoking. It has really got nothing to do with that whatsoever. There were 660 tobacco farmers in Australia and now there are about 260. The reason for that was the removal of the marketing schemes that existed previously. If we got stuck into the oil companies and took them on-the same as that great and courageous President of the United States, Theodore Roosevelt, did at the start of this century-we would enjoy the same sorts of prices that are enjoyed in the United States. That would save this country $6,000 million. Just with those two commodities-wool and petrolthis country could save $9,000 million a year if we had a bit of backbone and aggression and took the same aggressive policies that were taken in the days of people like John McEwen and Sir Robert Menzies. To move on, there are some three or, arguably, six major water schemes in Australia which, if we proceed with them, as the Americans did during the Great Depression, will bring into this country $5,000 million a year. I have not got time to go into much detail here. As far as mining goes, if the laws with respect to the Native Title Act are put into place properly and if we stand up to the ridiculous obsession which some people have with the environment and which takes us into absolute lunacy areas, then we will produce for this country great wealth that is not being produced at the present moment. In just six mines in North Queensland and at the top of Western Australia there is $5,000 million worth of production being held up, some of it indefinitely, because of those twin problems that exist in Australia today. In the prawn farming industry, the greenies are winning to such an extent that prawn farming is actually going down-production is actually going down in this country-because they are succeeding in closing more farms than we can open. So a tiny little country like Thailand, with a coastline about one-twentieth the size of Queensland's coastline or maybe even less than that, is producing $2.2 thousand million worth of prawns a year, whereas Australia is producing from her prawn farms under $100 million a year. And that figure, in all probability at the present moment, is falling. So there is $2,000 million in prawn farming alone to add to that list. Moreover, in the area of ethanol phosphate and converting a lot of our transportation systems to electricity there is another $2,000 million that this country can make but is not making at the present moment. Those micro-schemes, specific target areas, are worth $23,000 million a year to the Australian economy. If we are looking for money, surely primage is the way to go. All the federal government's income before the First World War came from primage, which is simply a charge on every single product coming into this country, an across-the-board charge. I cannot quote you the section from GAIT, but it is GAIT neutral. The income can be bought in that way at 10 per cent and will most certainly give our struggling manufacturing industries-and even, now, some of our food industries-some desperately needed respite against countries where people are forced to work for $2 a day. We should move into the area of income splitting. You may want to know why we have the highest juvenile suicide rate in the world. In a single-income family, where a bloke is Thursday, 19 September 1996 MAIN COMMITTEE 4817 working and the wife chooses to stay at home and look after her kids properly, if the husband is on the average Australian income he starts with $34,424. After tax is taken out he is left wi th $26,182. If there are four people, including his wife and two children, that works out at $6,500 each. That is what they have got to get by on. If it is a double-income family, where the wife chooses to work, they are on $52,364 a year after tax is taken out. That leaves them on $14,000 a year each. But if it is a DINK family-double income and no kids-as so many Australian families are today, they are on $26,000 each. Mr Deputy Speaker, I ask you: would you like to be on $6,500 a year each or would you like to be on $26,000 a year each? If you are a DINK you are on $26,000. If you are like me and like so many of the rest of us and your wife chooses to look after your children, and if you are on the average Australian income, you are on $6,500 a year each. That is the reason why women are being forced out into the work force against their will. That is the reason why our young people truly are so unhappy today that they are doing away with themselves. (Time expired) a first-class speech on behalf of his constituents. He would make a good Independent member, as a matter of fact. WhatI want to say at the beginning of my speech relates to the fact that we are debating the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1996-97, a very important bill, here in the Main Committee, which was set up-as I well know, being a former member of the Procedures Committee at the time-to deal with non-contentious legislation. Here we are in the Main Committee, out of the main chamber, debating what is, effectively, the most important legislation of the year, and the government considers this to be part and parcel of a responsible working parliamentary democracy. I can say that that was outside the scope of the intent of the formation of the Main Committee, well outside. This was designed to deal with non-contentious legislation and it was designed to offer members the opportunity of speaking on those non-contentious bills for which, often, the speaking time had concertinaed because of more pressing government matters on the government legislative calendar. We find ourselves now here in this room debating, in effect in the secondary chamber of the House of Representatives, the most important piece of legislation the government has this year. In my view, this is an abrogation of the responsibility of the government. The government made it clear in the election campaign that it was going to raise the standards of parliamentary debate. It was going to improve the way in which we conducted our affairs. It was going to make the Speaker more independent. What we have, in effect, is the executive leaning on the House of Representatives and forcing the legislation which is, basically, going to fund a large amount of the government's election promises-and some of the things it did not promise in the election, which I am going to come to-to be debated here, away from the main stage in the main chamber. That is not only a shame; it is a disgrace. I have made that point clear elsewhere and I will continue to do so until the government realises that people in the wider community will not put up with this. Then it will have to change. The government, in essence, is using the power of its numbers to squash the opportunity for members to make their contribution in the main chamber of the House of Representatives. There are no ministers here, no parliamentary secretaries. Nobody is listening. Nobody is interested. That also, to my way of thinking, demonstrates the contempt that the executive government has for the contributions of individual members. In other words, all these things

speaker: Mr Filing (Moore) 01.04 A.m.)
theText: The member for Kennedy( Mr Katter) has just delivered4818 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 19 September 1996 that are occurring in the House of Representatives, either here or in the other chamber, are entirely irrelevant to the conduct of government business. The way in which the government is conducting itself is not only no better than the conduct of the previous administration, in many instances it is worse. It is more authoritarian and, in fact, it is more oppressive than the worse excesses of the Keating government-and believe me, they were bad enough. What is happening now is that the government is doing more than the Keating government did. The Keating government set up the Main Committee. I was an opponent of it in the first instance, because I believed that the Main Committee would relegate aspects of debate from the main chamber into the Main Committee and there would be a secondary debate. Members of the public probably would not even know this chamber exists, and the members of parliament would feel that their contribution was being treated with contempt. What we have, in essence, is exactly what I predicted, coming true now. But that is not under the Keating government: to be fair to the Keating government, for all the other excesses it brought to the Australian parliament, the Keating government never referred other than non-contentious legislation to this Committee, except in a couple of instances when it was pulled up, quite rightly, by individual members. I just make this observation: if the government thinks this sort of thing is going to go on unchallenged, it has another think coming. It really has to fulfil the promise it made to the electorate in the election campaign, that it was going to make parliamentary debates, the parliamentary processes, more relevant to the community. It would raise them, to make sure that the government and the parliamentary process was an effective part of our system of governance. We in this place would all know in the bottom of our hearts that much of what we might say and much of what we might do, as far as the government is concerned, is worth nothing, because it chooses purely to ignore it. We have seen occasions in recent times when the government has chosen to use numbers to crush individual motions. One instance was, in my view, a dreadful occurrence: a member who chose to move two similar divisions was ruled to be obstructionist and the second division was considered to be out of order. That is interesting, compared with the situation where the Labor opposition has moved three divisions on exactly the same thing but they have not had the same ruling applied to them. It is interesting that there seems to be one rule for some and another rule for the others. The general thrust of the budget, in most areas, is commendable. I know that the member for Kennedy and others share some very strong reservations about the economic rationalist aspects of the government's agenda, and I do too. But there are a number of areas where the government has been forced into accepting greater fiscal accountability and responsibility as its essential duty to the community. After all, we are here, in essence, dealing with the expenditure of taxpayers' money, and we have a very substantial duty to make sure that is done properly, it is accountable and transparent. In more recent times the member for Kalgoorlie ( Mr Campbell) pointed out that, in the Primary Industries Amendment Bill which was before this place some time ago, there was a $24 million appropriation from the non-wool assets of wool farmers to what was called Wool Holdings International, which was a body designed to encourage the sale of wool on the futures market. And how much description was there, in the documentary material which accompanied the bill, about what that was going to be used for? There were two lines in the explanatory memorandum. Did that arouse much interest or concern on the part of the Thursday, 19 September 1996 MAIN COMMITTEE 4819 government? Very little at all. It is incredible that $24 million can be appropriated with only two lines of explanatory memorandum. That is incredible. That is $12 million per line. It is a very expensive explanatory memorandum. But there are a few areas in the budget which I would like to address now and they cause me some concern. I was elected in Moore as the Independent member with, in my view, a role to play to try and ensure, as much as I am able, that the promises that the government made in the election campaign are kept. I have to say that a number of them have not been kept, and there are a number of things in the budget which were not foreshadowed. Some people have found them to their cost. The government cannot talk on the one hand of providing incentives for development, prosperity and the public good and then place legislative and administrative fiscal disincentives in the way. I am going to address a few areas where I think that the government can provide innovation and improvement. One is a light fuel oil excise rebate, something the member for Kennedy would know about because this also affects, I would imagine, areas of his own electorate. It is a matter of considerable concern to regional Australians, especially those in Western Australia and Queensland. The government made a very good decision, in my view, to leave in place the excise exemption for light fuel oil used in the mining and farming industries. I was one of those that lobbied the government to try and ensure that this took place. But I am concerned that the government has not addressed the anomaly created by the previous government where the rebate was removed for power generation. Regional and remote Australia are very dependent on distillate based power generation and thus are highly vulnerable to any increases that occur in fuel pricing. Most electricity consumption in regional and remote areas is directly related to mining and primary industry activities. So there is a little bit of a dilemma or an incongruous situation here. The government has imposed an excise on the fuel used by utilities generating electricity for consumption by the mining and primary industry sectors, and yet it provides exemptions for distillate used by the mining companies in those sectors. The situation is being exacerbated by the previous government increasing the light fuel excise from 6.5c per litre to 33c per litre. In my state, this increased Western Power's regional power division costs by $18 million, to a record $44 million loss. Western Power generates and distributes electricity to 19,000 customers in 29 regional towns from Esperance to Kununurra. Much of Western Power's electricity is subject to contractual arrangements where initial costs could not be passed on to major consumers. Western Power is subject to the national competition policy-which I am sure the member for Kennedy has some strong views about-which disallows subsidisation to the regional divisions with profits from the metropolitan operation. South Waleswill be significant price increases in electricity for regional users. Large regional users face an increase of 30c per kilowatt hour from July next year, compared to the total cost now of 12c per kilowatt hour for supply to a metropolitan household. So, there is a substantial disincentive for businesses operating directly or indirectly in support of mining and primary industries, and it has great implications for development and quality of life in regional WA.

speaker: Mr Filing
theText: I was going to say that the only recourse in the case of Western Australia4820 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 19 September 1996 This excise is an inequitable outback tax and it causes an inefficiency in infrastructure decisions and a significant burden to regional WA and to Queensland, I might add, where there are a number of areas where power is generated through diesel fuel. I call on the government to extend the light oil fuel rebate to cover the generation of electricity by utilities. The other aspect where I have got some substantial concerns is the cuts in low levels of federal funding in the budget for programs which are related to fighting and preventing crime. These budget cuts are damaging to the morale and effectiveness of organisations such as the AFP and the NCA. Public order and safety spending is decreasing significantly as a percentage of the total Commonwealth budget, and this is occurring when the risks to the community from crime continue to increase. The AFP is a principal law enforcement agency through which the Commonwealth pursues its law enforcement interests. This budget reduces funding for 1997 by $19.2 million in running costs, $1.2 million in outlays for plant and equipment, and $1.8 million in appropriations for buildings or works. The government gave an election commitment to increase funding for fraud investigation by the AFP. This cannot be maintained. This budget means that the AFP will lose staff and resources. The AFP has shown that there is a direct correlation between operational resources and operational performance. Cuts in resources here will mean a cut in narcotics seizures, investigated frauds and proceeds of crime confiscations. The reduction in the AFP's policing effort will affect the entire Australian policing operation. I share the concern of the Police Federation of Australia that this funding reduction puts at risk the whole reform program for the AFP. I might add that in my home state it is estimated there is $1 billion of illicit drugs entering over the state border per annum. I might also say that in the face of funding cuts in Australian Customs, the NCA, the AFP, and the Western Australian Police Force-in effect, real cuts-we are going to see a significant problem become even more of a concern. In Western Australia we have significantly higher crime rates than the Australian average. As I have described before, Australia is a place where you are far more likely to have your home burgled or to be robbed or assaulted without a weapon than in the United States. This is something a lot of people do not realise. Crime is on the increase. It is a serious problem. AndI am appalled that the government has chosen to target the AFP in particular for those significant funding cuts, as well as the NCA. The Australian Institute of Criminology was established to conduct research, policy analysis and information dissemination on criminal justice issues. It is a valuable resource in our nation's fight against crime. It has meant, in effect, that the state police services have not had to devote resources of their own to similar statistical research. But there is one particular aspect of it that I am sure the member for Adelaide (Ms Worth) would be concerned about too. That is that the budget statement relating to the Australian Institute of Criminology has proposed the discontinuance of the AIC's violence against women project. I would have thought that members of the government would be appalled at that particular prospect. It is something that I hope they will work within their party fora to have overturned. It has a direct application in the fight against violence against women. We know that that is a matter of very serious concern in Australia, not only to women but to all responsible members of the community. Under the circumstances, given that the state police forces have used the Australian Institute of Criminology statistical research for their own particular Thursday, 19 September 1996 MAIN COMMITIEE 4821 workings, I would have thought that that was a matter for grave concern on the part of government members who I know share my concerns about the problems of violent crime against women-and, of course, domestic violence as well. The dental program is another area where there have been some serious concerns. In effect, the cessation of the dental program is really a decision to underfund the last year of the program by half. We know that dental care delivery is a state responsibility. But the Commonwealth did develop the program to meet the high level of need in the community for this type of support. There is not any great evidence of a reduction in the demand, and I am concerned to a certain extent that the measure is short-sighted. In the circumstances, knowing that dental care is an important component of health care, I think we will see an increase of costs in general health delivery as a result, because the interesting thing is that if you do not get your teeth sorted out, often that can lead to other health problems. We know that in a lot of cases, and certainly from the past, dental health care was considered to be one of the most important aspects of personal health care because of the primary fact that we have to use our mouths in order to be able to eat and drink. Therefore, dental health care is of significance and I call on the government to increase state funding that can be directly attributable to dental care because of the circumstances I have just mentioned. The changes to deeming for pensioners is another area of concern. They say it is a measure to simplify and reduce the intrusive nature of the taxation system. Independent commentators have stated that the effect of this change is that pensioners must ensure that their money must achieve a return of at least five per cent to avoid being disadvantaged. I have stated that I am opposed to any measures taken by the government that will disadvantage pensioners. I am sure many of the members of the governmentA division having been called in the House of RepresentativesSitting suspended from 11.19 to 11.34 a.m. rules for pensioners and to reinstate the previous exemption of the first $2,000 for singles and $4,000 for couples. Given the difficulty in gaining the five per cent return after operating costs in their working accounts that the original exemption was designed to provide for, I will continue to oppose this measure. It is unfair. It is, in my view, an unnecessary burden on pensioners. It is a burden that, in the first instance, was placed on pensioners to bring about some sort of fairness in relation to the likely unearned income that pensioners might be achieving with some of their financial assets. But, in this case, it is purely and simply an extra whammy on pensioners that they do not deserve. In the time that I have left, I want to address a couple of points. One is in relation to AQIS. The federal government funding for both the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service and the Customs Service remains inadequate in relation to the risks our community faces. AQIS must be made efficient and maintained as such. This is not just in terms of its inspection and prophylactic services but also, most importantly, in terms of the quality of advice it gives to the government. We have the potential to further develop as a major producer of safe, healthy foodstuffs throughout the region. This is at constant risk from imported pests and diseases. Recently, serious weeds such as cleavers and red shank have entered Australia in canola seeds from New Zealand. Other introduced pests include the golden apple snail, which poses a serious risk to

speaker: Mr Filing
theText: I call on the government to reverse its decision on the extension of deeming4822 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 19 September 1996 the rice industry, and fire blight, which could seriously affect our apple production and devastate our pear industry. The potential damage to Australian industry if infected products such as cooked chicken meat or salmon products are allowed to be imported is enormous. With AQIS funding at its present levels, this becomes more highly likely. The government must have confidence in the advice of AQIS, and AQIS and the government must be accountable for the actions taken under the advice. In this matter, I give notice to the government that I intend, along with the member for Kalgoorlie, to move a private member's bill to make the Commonwealth government of the day more responsible for the losses that are incurred by producers as a result of decisions made under the advice of AQIS. Finally, I will go back to the point that I made at the beginning in relation to our system of parliamentary democracy. I will make some comments in relation to some changes to the constitution that are absolutely necessary. I recognise and applaud the fact that the funding appropriated in this bill is directly related to the implementation of one of the most wide-ranging changes in direction for Australian society. There was a mandate in the election for the government to implement that program and they are in the process of implementing most of it, some of it in areas which were not foreshadowed. Industrial, social education and employment characteristics will be dramatically altered. The number of government members attests to the very high level of public support for change. But it was not necessarily support for change to a Liberal coalition government. It was a call for a change from the community which had been absolutely sick to its back teeth of 13 years of Labor's inefficient and, in many instances, corrupted government. This government has announced its intentions to make government fiscally accountable and responsible. I believe that it is time for them to also become legislatively accountable and responsible. In our society we have witnessed a growth industry in political correctness. We have seen relatively small vested interest groups take control of various issues and, eventually, government. This has occurred relatively easily, despite being contrary to the will of the vast majority of the people. The Westminster system is becoming more cut off from the will and the rights of the people. In essence, the executive virtually operates in an untrammelled fashion vis-a-vis the parliament, the House of Representatives and the Senate. We have the situation where, in many instances, the rights and interests of constituents of the members of the House of Representatives are unable to be fulfilled purely and simply because they do not fit in with the program or the will of the executive. We must allow the Australian people as a whole the right and responsibility to introduce or amend legislation by the power of their votes. I am referring to what are generally known as citizen initiated referenda. I believe the absence of a mechanism for citizen initiated referenda reduces the quality of our parliamentary democracy and also reduces the accountability of our judicial system to those it is meant to serve. I give notice that I will shortly be introducing a bill to provide for an alteration to the constitution to enable the making of laws on the initiative and popular request of electors. The Westminster system of parliamentary democracy is under a great deal of questioning, scrutiny and threat. We have a system that has evolved over a long period of time. Because Thursday, 19 September 1996 MAIN COMMITTEE 4823 of this imbalance between the power of the executive and the power of the parliament, we are seeing, in essence, an executive dictatorship in this country, not what was originally envisaged-parliamentary democracy. The system needs to be changed. It needs to be changed to be more accountable to the people. It must be more accountable to the people through the processes of the parliament and, of course, through the diligence and efforts of the individual members representing their constituents. (Time expired) families, business, industry and youth are heading in the right direction, after an abysmal betrayal of their future by the previous Labor government. I rise to speak on this Appropriation Bill (No.1). Debt and deficit were all we were passing on to our future generations after 13 years of fiscal irresponsibility. The Australian community were led down the yellow brick road by a pied piper who cajoled everyone into believing his tune was the only beat to move to. The Australian taxpaying public were in for a big surprise when the Treasury books were opened to reveal what we all know now: not just the devastating $7 billion deficit that we found initially upon gaining government, but a disastrous final figure of $10 billion. We did not create the problem, but we will fix it. This is the whole purpose of the measures taken by Treasury to restore the economy to surplus. This will not happen without the measures outlined by the Treasurer ( Mr Costello) in the budget documents for 1996-97. The legacy of previous Labor budgets, of their failure to cut government spending and their reliance on high interest rates, undermined Australian families and businesses. Under Labor, home mortgage rates hit 17 per cent. Interest rates went up nearly three per cent between August and December 1994. Family household debt rose to over $200 million. The current account deficit reached nearly $2.7 billion in May 1995, the worse figure ever since the statistics began to be collected. Under Labor, nearly one million Australians were out of work. Under Labor, Working Nation, the greatest failure, cost the Australian taxpayer $3.5 billion. What a waste on labour market programs. Previous budgets increased wholesale sales taxes by two per cent, from 20 to 22 per cent; increased petrol tax; increased excise on tobacco by 15 per cent; reduced the growth of defence spending; changed HECS so repayments commenced earlier and at higher rates; realigned HECS with income tax arrangements so repayments reflected the proportion of the year in which those with HECS obligations earned above the repayment threshold; increased the Medicare levy by 0.1 per cent, to 1.5 per cent; increased tax on motor vehicles by six per cent, from 15 per cent to 22 per cent; increased company tax from 33 to 36 per cent; increased PAYE tax payments to bi-monthly for small businesses-and the list goes on. On2 March, Australians reassessed their priorities. On2 March, Australians had had enough. On 20 August, the new government outlined the new direction for fiscal responsibility. For families, business, older Australians and those in genuine need, the 20 August budget met our core commitments. The family tax initiative means that a family with two dependent children, earning less than $70,000 per year and taking out private health insurance, will get a tax break of $51.90 per fortnight. That is $450 a year. These measures will have a positive effect on the constituents in my electorate of Bowman. In fact, one such family, the Mauds, were quoted in my local paper as saying: It's terriiic. We weren't expecting any family assistance. We didn't think the country could afford it. They went on to say that, while a $17 a week tax rebate on their health insurance costs did not sound like much, it would certainly help. They said:

speaker: Mrs West (Bowman) (11.40 A.m.)
theText: The mediumto long-term prospects for Australian4824 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 19 September 1996 It'll make it a lot more comfortable. The paper pointed out that the Mauds arc typical of the type of family in the Bowman electorate. But in my electorate it is not just families who will reap benefits from this budget. The small business sector have expressed their satisfaction with the measures announced, in particular the move to reduce the deficit which has resulted in a reduction to interest rates. Business is understandably wary of claims made by politicians, and why would it not be? For 13 years business has suffered from the broken promises and inept administration of the Labor Party. Business, particularly the small to medium business sectors, was the punching bag of the former Labor administration. 'We need more money? Let's tax business,' seemed to be the creed of the former Lahor government. One of my small businessmen. who was struggling, has described the impact of the previous government on business as a severe bruising. The bruising that business received was in the form of taxation, duplication, employee related issues. licences and complexity. So it is little wonder business is still wary of governments and politicians. It is the job of this government to regain the trust and confidence of business, and we have already begun Lhe process. These businesses can rest assured that the deregulation task force set up by the Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs( Mr Prosser) is addressing the concerns of small business in putting priorities in a less time consuming way. As I mentioned earlier, interest rates arc on the way down, with the most recent drop bringing the rate on variable loans down from 11.25 per cent to 10.75 per cent. This translates to a total saving of up to $2,500 a year for small business with a variable rate loan. This also represents 40 per cent of all small business loans. To this effect, Mr Deputy Speaker, I have decided to conduct a forum in my electorate to bring together all the interested parties that are going to deal with the future business in Bowman. It is called a business forum and we are looking at addressing the needs of business. We will bring government members and government advisers together to listen to small business and hopefully promote a strategic plan to address the problems in the area. The new apprenticeship and traineeship scheme will also assist business with employers being eligible for a commencement payment of $1,250 for each apprentice or trainee, a $1,250 progress payment and a bonus for each one taken on above the previous year's intake. Obviously this measure will not only benefit the small to medium enterprises but also benefit the unemployed. The government will spend $207 million over the next four years on the new apprenticeship scheme. That means real jobs for the unemployed, not the never ending training programs that were designed for one purpose: to keep these unemployed off the unemployed numbers list. The former administration spent over $3.5 million on labour market programs that did not work. In fact, two-thirds of the long-term unemployed are still unemployed after going through a Working Nation program. In direct contrast the coalition government will get these people back to work in jobs that last longer than the length of their course. We will be encouraging the skillshare organisations to move with us and restructure to cope with the changing needs of the Australian people. On a recent trip to Queensland the Leader of the Opposition ( Mr Beazley) and his entourage of hasbeens and wannabes tried to make political mileage by visiting one of my skillshares. His efforts went largely unrewarded as he was forced to admit that the skillshare he visited would survive. I have commended this skillshare for their ingenuity, their responsibility and their accountability. I endorse their management practices and I have encouraged them to continue. Thursday, 19 September 1996 MAIN COMMITTEE 4825 Further to this, the manager of this skillshare was quoted in the local paper as saying his organisation was putting a positive light on the changes and would adapt to them. This goes to show how out of touch with the electorate the Leader of the Opposition is and why the coalition is in government and he is in opposition. The Labor Party has obviously learnt nothing from the lessons handed to them by the Australian people on 2 March. At the other end of the spectrum, the government has recognised the significant contribution the elderly have made to the development of this nation and has introduced measures to assist these people enjoy their retirement years. One such couple from my electorate were quoted in the Courier-Mail as saying, 'The 1996-97 federal budget was one of the most encouraging ever for senior citizens.' Bill Clarke, who is the spokesperson for the National Seniors Association, and who is a constituent of mine, went on to say that it was a sensible budget that tries to overcome previous budget shortcomings and Australia's senior citizens have fared extremely well. The raising of the tax-free threshold for self-funded retirees to $11,185 has been well received in my electorate as has the initiative which allows seniors to contribute to a superannuation scheme up to the age of 70. This flies in the face of the scaremongering of the opposition, which is targeting the pensioners of Australia because they are seen as an easy target. The opposition is continuing its attack on the introduction of a voluntary entry contribution fee for nursing homes. I say 'voluntary' because that is exactly what it is-a voluntary fee which will be paid by those who can, not as the opposition would have us believe a flat $26,000 fee on all people who enter a nursing home. I have had a number of calls to my electorate office from pensioners who were worried that they would have to sell their family home should they wish to go into a nursing home. Fortunately, I have been able to ease their anxiety by explaining that the contribution does not apply to those on a full pension, and nursing homes can in no way force someone to pay. These people deserve better than the treatment being handed out by the opposition. Mr Deputy Speaker, I will tum my attention now to the environment-a subject which is very dear to my heart. My electorate of Bowman includes the magnificent Moreton Bay. The bay is one of the most significant breeding grounds for a large variety of marine animals, and it must be protected at all costs. It is also a great tourist destination. The government has provided funding to the tune of $1.8 million for research into aquaculture in my electorate. The projects that will be conducted by the Cleveland division of the CSIRO will provide the fishing industry with vital information on fish stocks and the replacement rate of the stock. At the same time, we need to be looking at the pollution of the bay. The government's proposed coasts and clean seas initiative is aimed at doing just this-keeping the bay clean. However, this will not be achieved without the partial sale of Telstra, which would allow the government to implement the most impressive and important piece of environmental legislation ever proposed-the Natural Heritage Trust of Australia. Mr Deputy Speaker, I commend the Treasurer and all ministers for their combined efforts in restructuring the fiscal directions of this country. I believe we are on the road to recovery, with very responsible and accountable strategies put in place by our very able executive. We look forward to a brighter future once we realise that we all have a part to play in making these policies work. 4826 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 19 September 1996 We were left in a desperate situation that needed addressing, and we will not back away from our commitment to address the economic mismanagement of the past 13 years. I am pleased to lend my strong support to the measures outlined in the budget documents of 1996. member for Bowman( Mrs West) because, as I have said to a number of her colleagues previously, they have a lot to learn in this place. Whilst they may genuinely believe the words that are being handed to them by their leadership, they are going to get one hell of a rude shock a little bit further down the path as we go forward. This budget is a budget of betrayal. It betrays the promises made to Australians in the run-up to the election. I will cover some of those promises a little later. It is a budget of deceit, because it is a budget that is presented in a manner that is designed to conceal the true impact of the budget, not to reveal it. It goes down in history as the first budget that anyone can recall which has been presented in this fashion. There will be a lot of examination of this budget to be done in time to come. I would refer those who doubt that to Hansard of 10 September' 1996, at page P3814, where my colleague the former Treasurer and member for Gellibrand ( Mr Willis) said that the budget outcome, as reported by the now Treasurer ( Mr Costello) for the past year, was a deficit of $10.3 billion. He went on to say: If we took no corrective measures it would be $9.6 billion this year. Those figures are not the budget outcome at all. The actual budget outcome for 1995-96 was a deficit of $5.045 million; that is, about half the figure given by the Treasurer. The forecast actual budget outcome for 1996-97 is not a deficit at all. It is a surplus of $464 million, which is forecast to grow to a surplus of $6,638 million in 1997-98. But these figures, of course, are not mentioned by the Treasurer in his speech because they would not fit in with his fiscal crisis rhetoric. I strongly recommend that members look through the speech on this issue delivered by the member for Gellibrand in the main chamber. I recommend particularly that our colleagues opposite do that, because they are hearing for the first time what this is all about, and they will see how they and the Australian public have been deceived. I do not have to say that to the member for La Trobe( Mr Charles). He is wiser and more knowledgeable; he knows it deep down; he can count, he can read and he can analyse. But he has to go with the party line at the moment. This is also a budget of broken promises. As I have said, it has been presented in a form designed to conceal the attacks it has made on major sections of our population. To the best of my knowledge, it is the first budget in Australia that has been based not on principles of sound economic management but on polls and surveys. It is a poll-driven budget that will harm specific sections of our community. This government has made decisions, based on surveys and polls, where it believes there are no votes to be lost. In fact, there may even be, in the current climate, some votes to be gained. Those attacks are aimed at people looking for work, and their families. Running through this first Howard-Costello budget is the same theme as ran through the Fraser-Howard budgets, budget after budget. I read all of their budget speeches last evening, just checking. They show the same old thing: people are unemployed because they want to be unemployed. The rhetoric that is in this budget is little different from the rhetoric back in the Howard budget speeches and all of the debates back in those periods of the Fraser-Howard government. A leopard does not change its spots. The Liberal Party has not learnt much, but it has forgotten nothing. It
