speaker: Mr Peter Morris (Shortland) (11.53 A.m.)
theText: I have some sympathy for the honourableThursday, 19 September 1996 MAIN COMMITTEE 4827 goes back to the same old thing: people who are unemployed are unemployed because they want to be unemployed. That is the most shameful approach to be taken in this country if we are talking about pulling this country together. There are people who will always have more difficulty in gaining employment than other people. There will always be people in the queue who have greater skills, better abilities and better training than others. Looking at the employment policies of this government, I find that what they are about is contained in the budget papers in the scrapping of the CES and the designing of a scheme of contracting out to the private sector the placement of people in jobs. Who will the private sector take? As we know from experience, they will take those who have the best prospects of getting placed. Who do they not take? Who are left on the scrap heap? The people who have greater difficulty. It is not their fault. That is one part of the problem. The other part of the problem is the economy. Looking at all of this budget and all of the projections, I find that it says-it is a wonderful objective, in their terms-that there will be no growth in employment. I will put it round the other way: there will be no decrease in the unemployment rate. So all of the prospects they are offering, all of the offers they are making and all of these changes are really about finding a way to cost or provide for their election promises, on the one hand, and concealing the fact that they really do not have a policy or a program that is going to reduce unemployment on the other. Let us move from people who are looking for work to immigrants. That is coming forward in speeches coming from other members of this House. That is another issue the government is dealing with. That can lay fair and square right across their shoulders. It will come back to haunt them later on. This is divisiveness. This is setting Australians against Australians. Like it or not-and you might not like it, on the other side of this committee-ours is a multicultural society. It is a nation drawn from many different cultures that have lived in harmony, worked in harmony and progressed this country. This country has benefited from their presence and their contributions. A number of us in this committee at the moment come from differing backgrounds. What this budget is about and what this government is about is dividing those groups. Let there be no mistake about this. The other group that comes from the poll surveys is that of Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders. Let this also rest on the shoulders of government members opposite, both in the committee and in the chamber. You will wear the acrimony for this later. It is clearly in your budget, in the measures you have taken and in the language used prior to and since the election. The one that really worries me is the attack upon sick, aged Australians. The other attack is upon working women. But in respect of sick, aged Australians, why is it that, out of the blue, a program like the Commonwealth dental health program, for which organisations campaigned literally for years, is abolished? Almost half a million Australians utilised that program in the last financial year. In my own electorate of Shortland, in the Hunter region and in the Central Coast region which my electorate embraces, over 7,000 people used that program last year and benefited from it. Why is it suddenly abolished? Again, it is an attack on the aged. They think, There is not going be much response there. They will not be a worry. We have got avery, very big margin and we can wear any response that might come from that. ' 4828 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 19 September 1996 But then it goes to the next step-the increase in the pharmaceutical benefits charge with no corresponding increase in the allowance for people with health cards. Why is it? It is the same target. Then the next step is an entry fee to get into a nursing home. So if you have got bad teeth, and you are aged, bad luck. You are going to pay. If you need medicines, you are going to pay. But when you get to the worse stage, when you really need to be in a nursing home, then you pay up or you do not get the treatment. And don't let's have any of this fussing around the edges and saying, 'Oh yes, but the nursing home does not have to demand the contribution.' If you are getting the full rate pension, if you are on a base rate pensionAdelaide interjects. You will not get in. colleague; you can't run away from your own actions. These are your actions. Why are you attacking aged Australians like this? But, worse, why are you attacking sick, aged Australians? Why are you doing this? This illustrates the callousness, the ruthlessness of a government that is really out of control. You target a group like this-aged, ill Australians-but then you say, 'Oh yes, they could dispose of their property.' The Treasurer ( Mr Costello) said, 'Well they could sell the property.' Have you thought about what is involved? It means somebody who is ill enough to need to be in a nursing home, who is in that condition and that frame of mind, is going to be told, 'You might be ill, you might be sick and you might need to be placed in a nursing home, but you are certainly fit enough to go out and negotiate the sale of your property.' The inhumanity and ruthlessness of that is something I have never seen beforenever even contemplated. But you can add to that the Medicare offices. They have this wonderful idea of Medicare offices. 'We'll close down the Medicare offices that are functioning efficiently' -I have the Belmont Medicare office in my electorate scheduled for closure-'and people will be able to go into selected pharmacies.' Not all pharmacies-these are yet unnamed pharmacies. In the budget documents it says people will be able to go in and lodge a fax. Have you thought of the retired person who has not yet gone to a nursing home, who needs medication and has been to the doctor? That person goes across to the pharmacist and has to make a claim to Medicare because they have had insurance-and this is the insurance that the government wants them to have. They have to be fit enough to operate a new piece of technology-and if they don't know, learn how to do it-and then get a credit made to their bank account, go down to one of the supermarkets and key in the amount they want to withdraw. Just think about the impracticality of that and the burden that imposes upon people in that age group. theText: You can twist those statistics as much as you like. We are talking about4834 MAIN COMMITIEE Thursday, 19 September 1996 tough decisions. The member for Shortland, once again, fell into the trap of trotting out the rhetoric that we have heard from opposition speaker after opposition speaker here in his criticism of our nursing home policies. Mr Deputy Speaker, I have a lot of nursing homes in my electorate and, I think, the oldest demographic group in the country. SoI am very close to what is happening in that area. I believe that the end result of our reform of nursing homes will be overwhelmingly positive for older people. It is a disappointment to me and to many others that the opposition has perhaps seen a little bit of an opportunity here to criticise an element of that policy. But, in the end, what they have done, and what they set about doing, is to frighten older people into believing that there is something draconian or something inherently unfair about this policy. What they have done is to misrepresent and distort that policy. They have seen just a glimmer of an opportunity to do that, and they have jumped right in. When I have been putting people in the picture about that policy, I have been able to defend it entirely, because it is defensible. The end line of that policy-the former government would not take the step-is that we will have better quality aged care. What could be more desirable than that? What could be fairer than the underlying principle here, which was always subscribed to by the former government, that people who can afford to pay for this--or anything else, if it comes to that-should be required to do so? That is the essential element of this particular policy. It extends to nursing homes the principle that the former government introduced in respect of hostels. It means that people who can afford to make a relatively small contribution will be asked to do so. There is nothing unreasonable about that. Mr Deputy Speaker, the unfairness of the opposition's misrepresentation is that they thought, 'We will jump in and attempt to frighten as many old people as possible into believing that somehow there will no longer be a nursing home place for them, unless they either have the money or sell the family home.' But neither of those criticisms is true. We have made the point over and over again, although opposition members do not want to hear it, that people will not be required to sell the family home to move into a nursing home and people who cannot afford to pay will simply not have to pay. The principle of that is sound, and it is a principle that the former government always accepted. This has been one of only a couple of very small windows of opportunity for criticism in this budget, and the opposition has jumped on it in an attempt not to make a small opening in the window, but to throw it wide open and make people think that there is actually something draconian about this policy. I am happy to stand up here, as I have stood up in my own electorate-which, demographically, is this group-and say to those people that our policy means better aged care. Not only that; it will also address the other fundamental problem that we had with the former government, and that was a chronic shortage of nursing home beds. There are people moving from one respite situation to another, at a very critical stage of their life, who cannot find a permanent nursing home bed. The former government did nothing to address that problem. Everything was wrong with the current system, especially the funding complexities. The member for Shortland went a little further down the track in trying to frighten my constituents, the older demographic group, about access to Medicare offices. Once again, he failed, in terms of recognising the fact that access to a Medicare office has been and is a problem. Our solution to that, which is a practical and sensible solution, is to provide additional facilities where people can have access to Medicare offices. There is no suggestion in that-the member for Shortland tried to say that there was that this will somehow make it difficult for older people. For a start, most of my aged constituents do not even go to a Medicare office. They do not even need to go. They go to a doctor, where their needs are taken care of, and they are bulk-billed for that service. We have indicated that that will continue. But for people who do need access to Medicare offices, for all sorts of reasons, we will increase the availability of that service. Nothing the member for Shortland said and nothing any member of the opposition can say about that can deny that fact. They can try and frighten as many people as they like, particularly older people, into somehow thinking that this is a major backdown on some aspect of health care policy. In fact it is again an improvement in the status quo and I applaud that policy. My electorate welcomes that policy overwhelmingly and fortunately most of the people in my electorate understand what the benefits of that additional access to Medicare facilities represent for them. The coup de grace, if you like, for the member for Shortland, from my perspective, is that he wants to get into the area of family policy. This a matter that is on the agenda in the main chamber today and it is a debate that I am looking forward to participating in very much, Mr Deputy Speaker. If there is one policy area that I have taken an interest in here, amongst a number of others I suppose, it is certainly the area of family policy. I stand here today in this chamber as I will in the main chamber later, very proud of the commitment of this government, as the budget indicated and underlined, to Australia's families. Australia's families were forgotten by the former government. The former government was diverted into all sorts of appeasement of minority groups and a whole range of activities, but in the end they forgot about the traditional Australian nuclear family which after all is the fundamental unit of our society. I believe that was a fundamentally important reason why the former government was defeated at the last election. It had simply forgotten the mainstream. It had forgotten the important part that families play. The member for Shortland attempted to criticise the new policy direction that we have now introduced. Underlying that policy-and he was particularly critical of the implications for child care-was our commitment to providing choice for Australian families. Australian families said on 2 March they were sick of the government telling them how to run their lives. Our policies are aimed at giving families choice-choice in child care, choice about whether both parents go out to work-and an end to conscription for mothers who overwhelmingly indicated they would prefer to stay at home and look after their children. 4836 MAIN COMMI1TEE Thursday, 19 September 1996 I dispute everything that the member for Shortland has said about what has been an excellent first Howard government budget. economic rationalists and nobody would seriously urge a return to economic irrationalism. In the 1970s a global economy developed, breaking down traditional trade barriers and the goal of national self-sufficiency. Economics rose and rose as the dominant intellectual paradigm and driving force in politics and administration. In the 1970s and 1980s economics became overwhelmingly dominant in government thinking in the West and human activity was measured by its ability to meet 'the bottom line.' It also contributed to a top down political model in which major parties competed with each other to show their toughness in making essentially short-term economic decisions, despite evidence that voters were seriously alienated. This has led to a loss of confidence in the legitimacy of governments, even democratically elected ones-a profoundly worrying phenomenon. The 1996-97 Costello budget illustrates, in a crassly triumphalist way, 20 major fallacies, and I appeal to Hansard to print my speech in the format as I set it out, including the inverted commas. The 20 fallacies: 1. 'That economics is a destination not just a vehicle.' 2. 'That economic values are more important than political or social ones.' 3. 'That the urgent must have priority over the important.' 4. 'That precisely quantifiable economic targets can be set.' 5. 'That Treasury has a wonderful track record in forecasting.' I listened to many maiden speeches by members elected on 2 March with their heavy emphasis on family values and wondered how far they realised those values were undermined, not reinforced, by the dogmas of economic rationalism. The idea that every value has a dollar equivalent is repellent but inescapable, especially in sport, but it applies increasingly in education and health too. With a gross domestic product of almost $500 biIlion, the highest OECD growth rate, the third lowest debt to GDP ratio in the OECD and a high degree of social stability, the battle cry of 'Woe to the vanquished' and frenzied pursuit of the arbitrary, largely mythical, 'black hole' is extraordinarily misplaced. As the Prime Minister( Mr Howard) has conceded when overseas, he inherited an economy in very good shape. The rhetoric of the Treasurer ( Mr Costello) is quite contrary. Treasurers, on both sides of politics, can become obsessed with targets expressed in absolute numbers, rather than a range of figures, plus or minus, say, 2 per cent. It then becomes a demonstration of masculinity to be able to reach the magic, if arbitrary, goal. The amount of damage caused, for example, to long-term activity such as education, research or culture is quite out of proportion to the actual sums saved in short-term cuts. It might seem self-evident that a five per cent cut across the board for, say, CSIRO or the ABC, will lead only to a five per cent reduction in activity. But it does not work like that. Most budget allocations are locked up in salaries and other inescapable outgoings. theText: Mr Deputy Speaker, in a sense we are allThursday, 19 September 1996 MAIN COMMITTEE 4837 the difference between viability and non-viability, a point very well made by Dickens's Mr Micawber. An efficiency dividend might seem appropriate where applied to some areas where the range of activity is finite-for example, processing Medicare accounts or taxation transactions-but mindless when applied, say, to the acquisition of books for the National Library or setting goals for research into radio astronomy. What does it mean: 'Last year you measured 1,000 stars; this year cut it down to 970'? A research project can be destroyed with the slash of a Finance bureaucrat's word processor. It may never be restored. Short-term factors dominate. The much publicised '$8 billion black hole' is a completely arbitrary figure, relying on the assumption that the Treasury forecasts are infallible. Note that the government insists on setting absolute numbers in the budget, aimed as it is at discrediting the Hawke-Keating government, but refuses-rightly, I think-to do it in unemployment where it would be the victim if the magic target was not met. Even if the $8 billion figure were correct, it could be covered in a variety of ways: one, cutting expenditure; two, raising revenue by a small adjustment to the tax rate; or three, a judicious mixture of one and two. The Treasurer's choice is to slash and bum. For example, eliminating the dental program for the aged was harsh to the victims but saved only $400 million to the revenue over a fouryear period. The Treasury does not have a wonderful record in forecasting and has been wrong in predicting growth rates and interest rates. It gave spectacularly bad advice on interest rates during the recession of 1990-91. 6. 'That Australia is a highly taxed country.' In 1993, of total tax revenue as a percentage of GDP at market prices, of 24 OECD countries Australia ranked second lowest at 28.7 per cent. Only Turkey was lower, at 23.5 per cent. Japan was at 29.1 per cent and the US at 29.7 per cent. The OECD average was 38.7 per cent. 7. 'That Australia has an unduly large public sector.' One might expect that in a huge country with a federal system there would be a very large public sector and some degrees of duplication. In OECD's National Accounts 1996, in a table setting out current general government revenue as a percentage of GDP, Australia ranked as one of the three lowest: US, 31.7 per cent; Japan, 32.9 per cent; Australia, 33.5 per cent. Canada, with which Australia has much in common-a large country with a federal system-stands at 33.5 per cent. Government employment as a percentage of total employment is also relatively low: 16.6 per cent. Some nations, curiously, have higher government expenditure but lower employment: Germany, Ireland, Italy, Luxembourg, Netherlands, Spain, Switzerland. The US figure is 14.5 per cent-far below us-and Japan's is an unusually low 5.9 per cent. 8. 'That foreign debt is largely due to government borrowing.' Deregulation of the financial market after 1983 led to a winding down of controls on private borrowing and has been the largest single factor in increasing foreign debt. Incidentally, Australia has the third lowest public debt in the OECD. Of foreign borrowing-that is, gross debt-the Commonwealth government, plus the Reserve Bank, accounts for 15.3 per cent of the total. State governments are responsible for 17.8 per cent. Borrowing by public enterprises such as Telstra amounts to 6.1 per cent. Private sector borrowings amount to 59 per cent. With net foreign debt, the private sector accounts for 63 per cent. 9. 'That interest rates are "current account deficit driven".' This was stated as an absolute statement of fact by the Prime Minister in question time last week. The Parliamentary Library can find no evidence to support this. Despite variations in overseas ratings by Moody's and 4838 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 19 September 1996 Standard and Poors, all Australian governments have 'an immaculate record' in repaying, and this is the major factor for long term investors. Short term interest rates are set by the Reserve Bank. 10. 'That Australia's employment levels fell under Labor.' There was an employment revolution which began under Fraser, continuing under Hawke, Keating, and now Howard-a dual labour market with the paradox of high levels of unemployment and high levels of employment as well. It sounds like a contradiction in terms, but it is absolutely correct. What it means is that many people, for example, unskilled males who traditionally were in the labour force are now no longer in it and a number of people who traditionally were not in the paid labour force, particularly women, are now in it. So the result is that, in terms of the participation rate, we are at an historic high and we have the phenomenon-we are not Robinson Crusoe in this; it is shared with most countries of the OECD-of having high unemployment and high employment at the same time. But, with the dual labour market, it means that different sectors are involved in different ways. II. 'That cutting government expenditure will free up the economy and lead to job creation.' 12. 'That freeing up small business will generate many more jobs.' 13. 'That productivity can be increased without job loss.' There is absolutely no empirical evidence to support the last three points. This is, as Martin Luther might have said, 'justification by faith alone'. Productivity, of course, we see as being an OK word-everyone wants productivity. But productivity simply means the ratio between output and the number of people employed. In other words, if with higher productivity there must be job loss relative to output. That is what it means. 14. 'That there could be no gain without pain.' Wage cutting, and confusing flexibility with instability, will not produce a stronger economy. Countries with higher wage rates than Australia-for example, Sweden, Norway, Finland and Japan-are far more competitive internationally than Australia and have significantly lower unemployment rates than we do. The argument that we could only create jobs if we opened up the el cheapo end of the market is absolutely, totally fallacious. And indeed, to give the government credit, they are not even advancing any evidence. They simply assert it and leave it at that. 15. 'That government enterprises are necessarily less efficient than private.' This is an ideological obsession, quite ill-founded if we compare the record of Qantas versus Ansett, of the Commonwealth Bank versus Westpac, of Telstra versus British or French Telecom. The costs of telephoning London or Paris from Melbourne are far lower than the return call on a privatised system. Logic suggests that if the privatised system is much more efficient, then telephoning Australia from Britain or France should be a good deal cheaper. In fact, as every consumer will tell you, it is very much dearer. That suggests there is something wrong with the proposition. 16. 'That foreign ownership of Australian corporations will have no adverse domestic effects on employment or social policy.' The tragedy, with which all too many members are thoroughly well aware, is that if a corporate decision is made in Detroit, for example, to cut jobs, of course the people who make the decision have no community responsibility because they do not know the people, they do not know the areas, they do not live there, they do not have the social contact. The argument that a whole number of enterprises can simply go offshore and it will not have any social impact is a dangerous delusion. There are many people in the coalition parties who know better, in terms of their own experience as local members, Thursday, 19 September 1996 MAIN COMMITTEE 4839 but who, because of the way in which the system operates, are not quite in the position to speak out as they should. 17. 'That Australia can only rely on comparative advantage'; that is, David Ricardo's concept of comparative advantage. Our obsession has been that other than raw materials there was no other possible base for our economy. That is, again, a half-truth. Of course, the contribution of the primary sector, of agriculture and mining, is absolutely profound. But if we say, 'That is as far as we need go; nothing more to be said,' that is dangerously short-sighted. Australia's greatest single economic weakness has been our conspicuous failure, over many years, to address what I have called the 'inventory problem'; that is, the lack of high value added brand name goods and services for which there is international recognition and demand, the area of fastest growth in world trade for three decades. We see ourselves as exporters of high volume, low cost exports, and little more. We have utterly failed to grasp the nature of 'competitive advantage' -that it is not just a matter of cost in exports but of value, recognition and reputation. The Republic of Korea-within the next week or so to join the OECD-understands 'competitive advantage'. We do not. They had an economy absolutely in ruins in the mid1950s-nothing to build on at all. So, what they decided was not to pursue comparative advantage, because there was no area of comparative advantage for them, but to pursue competitive advantage-to find niche markets and develop quality products. We can all see the extraordinary intervention in the Australian market of the Hyundai motor car and the tremendous proportion of electronic products from Korea. What are the equivalent products that we are selling Korea? They are all staples-wheat, wool, coal and the basic metals. We export products measured in tonnes; they export to us products measured in grams. There is something wrong with that. I commend to those honourable members who have not already read it-although I know that you are a devotee of it, Mr Deputy Speaker-Michael Porter's great book, The Competitive Advantage of Nations, a textbook that everybody in this parliament should read. 18. 'That it is illegitimate for governments to be making choices' -also known as 'picking winners' 'in priority areas for innovation.' It is true that there may be some slight modification there. 19. 'That winding down R&D expenditure indicates that Government is giving it a higher priority.' It sounds a bit contradictory, and indeed it is. I remember John Elliott saying to me a few years ago, when I was trying to goad CUB into doing more R&D expenditure, 'What sorts of signals are you giving? If you are winding it down in levels of your expenditure and then you are saying to us, "You ought to be spending more," the signal is completely contradictory. If you don't think it is worth putting more money into it, why should weT This was a big defeat for the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and a win for the Treasurer. Cutting back R&D tax concessions from 150 to 125 per cent is estimated to save the revenue $2,247 million between 1996 and 2001. The Treasurer announced 'a flexible package of $340 million over the next four years to encourage highly innovative research and development'. But this involves a shortfall, overall, of nearly $2 billion. So, is it an advance, or is it a retreat? The final fallacy-one that I feel very badly about-is No. 20: 'That CSIRO did well in the budget.' In his budget speech, the Treasurer said: 4840 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 19 September 1996 The government will provide an additional $115 million over the next 4 years for CSIRO. That sounds very generous. In fact, it is totally deceptive. With the impact of extra efficiency dividends, and a requirement to repay asset sales, leaving inflation aside, CSIRO can expect to be $10.3 million worse off by the year 1999-2000. So, far from having a $115 million increase, they will be $10.3 million worse off, leaving inflation aside. In other words, what they have said is, 'Look, we'll provide the $115 million, but we will take it back from you. It looks good and we are not going to talk about the fact that the efficiency dividend has been cranked up.' I succeeded, in part, in getting the efficiency dividend wound down. I thought it was bad enough under our government. But it has now been re-imposed, right across the board, at a higher level. If people on the coalition side are not aware of that, they ought to be. They ought to be asking their minister raising it in their party rooms. This is a miserable, mean-spirited budget. It also has the politics wrong, because it is remote from the electorate and will be destructive to community values. The community is far more than a 'market'. The worse kind of bankruptcy is moral bankruptcy. Telling the truth might be a good start. I commend the amendment moved by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition and I hope honourable members will support it. in a school play. It was the story of the king that had no clothes. It might not be surprising to those present that I was one of the tailors who conned the king into believing that we had made him a beautiful set of clothes at great cost when, of course, he went down the street in public naked. All the people were cheering and commenting on the magnificent clothes, until a very small child said, 'Mummy, the king's got no clothes on.' I make that point because today I would like to address the budget and the concept of how it and some of the contributions that have been made could be described as 'naked'. In the context of this debate, let me start with a statement of fact, which is that too many politicians measure excellence by expenditure. That leads me to the speeches of the member for Oxley (Ms Hanson) and the member for Aston( Mr Nugent). The member for Oxley, for instance, called for the closure of ATSIC. The member for Aston, in seeking to rebut the member for Oxley, quoted the acknowledged substandard living conditions of Aboriginal people. Unfortunately, I feel the member for Aston's examples were, in fact, substantial reasons for the disbanding of ATSIC and all the associated bureaucratic structures, such as the Aboriginal legal aid services and the Aboriginal medical services and land councils, that have so obviously failed to address the fundamental problems of the very disadvantaged people in Australia known as our Aboriginal people. While tens of millions of dollars are allocated in this budget to funding white lawyers to lodge land claims, there are many Aboriginal people with glaucoma who can no longer enjoy the beauty of their land. They simply cannot see it. Personally, I acknowledge the good intentions, on behalf of their constituents, of both members. The MP for Oxley, as the representative of an electorate where many white people are suffering low living standards and unemployment, feels that more attention to their problems is required and resents the special allocation to Aboriginals. The member for Aston concerns himself, quite properly, with the deprivation of the Aboriginal people, and wishes to give them help.
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Tuckey (O'connor) (12.52 P.m.)
theText: I remember, in my childhood days, performingThursday, 19 September 1996 MAIN COMMITTEE 4841 I wish to give positive and genuine assistance to both groups, and I am convinced that the current method of service delivery to Aboriginal people is a total failure. Not only is it not helping Aboriginals, but it is consuming large sums of money that might go to other disadvantaged people. In fact, in delivering decentralised, conventional, bureaucratic structures for the Aboriginal people, we have created a typical third-world hierarchy: a small group of very well-off Aboriginals and a poverty-stricken majority. I lack time today to develop this further, but my solution is a complete reversal of Aboriginal funding, from our current top-down funding system, to a bottoms-up system. I refer the parliament to my letter published in the Financial Review on 30 August. In this process I propose the total removal of all the current Aboriginal bureaucratic structures, including the Council for Reconciliation. In this regard, let me say that, if we want evidence of the efficiency of this institution, let me refer you to the community-not the media-reaction to the member for Oxley's public statement. If our pursuit is for reconciliation, why do we support in legislation a native title process that, at every stage, throws interest groups into direct confrontation with one another? In any other area of land management, state government administrations stand as the determinant and thus-if I can use the word-the enemy. At this stage, in my electorate and throughout my state we have Aboriginal in conflict with Aboriginal and Aboriginals in conflict with white people, and nobody is going anywhere. Surely, it is time that we found some clothes that the king might wear. Passing to the broader effect of the budget, let me say that I support its thrust, which is to stop the process of increasing indebtedness of our nation and the burden that that applies to future generations. Put simply, during the term of the previous Labor government, this parliament, using the children of Australia as security, borrowed $70,000 million and sold and consumed the proceeds of approximately $10 billion worth of public assets such as Qantas, CSL and the Commonwealth Bank. WhilstI have had to take these figures out briefly and quickly, it is an interesting fact to note that in 1991-92, when GDP growth was three per cent, the deficit of the government as a percentage of GDP was 2.6-almost the same. In 1992-93, the deficit as a percentage of GDP was 3.2-Australia's percentage growth of GDP was 4.2 per cent. The figures for 199394 were 4.3 per cent and four per cent, and I could go on. The next two years we found a somewhat wider gap of just one per cent but, in reality, they were the years when massive asset sales were brought to account to artificially reduce the budget deficit. Whilst my education in economics as a science was limited to my leaving school examination-at the end of my secondary schooling at Perth Modern School-after that I continued my education in the school of business hard knocks. Based on that experience, I must say that turnover growth-that is, Australia's GDP, which is entirely debt and asset-sale driven-is not sustainable growth, particularly when in this case the expenditure involved was almost entirely directed to consumption, rather than to capital works. For years, this country has boasted economic growth which was identical to the amount of money that the government borrowed in that year or which it otherwise accumulated by selling off the farm. With that sort of growth, we have a situation that can only take us backwards. Just briefly, let me look at the budget outlays therefore, by function, to show where the money has gone. In that regard, I want to refer to the massive growth that has occurred, for instance, in the provision of health services under Medicare. In just the life of that proposal, 4842 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 19 September 1996 we have seen a growth in outlays from about $3 billion to $19.4 billion. But worse, in terms of investing in the future, in that same time education outlays grew from $4 billion to $11 billion. So we are pouring money into a philosophical issue that never worried us once--called Medicare-and, in the same breath, we are cutting back on education which, surely, is an investment at government level in the future. It is like a business building a new factorysomething that is there forever. This budget reduces the government's expenditure by many billions of dollars and consequently curtails that accumulated debt. However, it also must have a downward effect on GDP growth which, in the national interest, must be filled by the private sector. The previous speaker, the member for Lalor( Mr Barry Jones), tried to recreate this myth that government debt does not have an effect on interest rates. But when you have a government pulling $10 billion or $15 billion a year out of domestic interest markets, of course it is having an effect. Furthermore, a lot of that paper, when sold, is bought by overseas interests and contributes to the nation's overseas debt. A number of criteria have to be met or the private sector will not fill this gap which has been created by a reduction in government expenditure. And it is a gap-government has been propping up this economy for 15 years and, as government ceases to do so, somebody else has to fill the gap or, yes, we will have economic decline. I am the first to admit it. But, as I said, the private sector will not fill this gap unless a number of criteria are met. These include the ability for business to hire and fire staff based on the staff's personal performance and the financial circumstances of the business. No-one sacks staff out of spite. That is a myth that has to be exploded. This myth has built up that people have to be protected from businessmen who get up in the morning and say, 'Who can I sack today?' I have talked to businessmen who have cried when they have had to put off staff-and I mean cried-because they did not know whether they could get such good people back when they recovered the financial circumstances of their business. The reality is that business does not hate its staff. It values it, but it has to have staff who perform. In times of economic downturn they have to have the right to put some of them off, and they cannot do that at this huge redundancy price. Their defence is just not to hire. The criteria that have to be met in order for the private sector to fill the gap also include the productivity value of such people based on international comparison. Productivity value does not imply lower wages, but does demand higher productivity per worker than occurs in low wage countries that compete with our industries at home and abroad. It was the previous government that took the decision to deregulate the financial market and lower tariffs, and I support that concept. But you cannot ask business to compete in that environment with a regulated labour market. It is just silly. The new industrial laws that are being proposed by the government are therefore essential. The argument of jobs for jobs' sake is just another king with no clothes. If Telstra employs 20,000 employees it does not need and passes the cost of those employees to industries who must compete with countries around the world, then those industries simply die or never develop. If employing public servants was the answer to unemployment, why not just double the size of the Public Service? We could fix the problem overnight-except that we haven't got the money to pay for it. Nevertheless, this budget is also topless, to say the least, because it fails to reform the Australian tax system. But the fact that it does not cannot be criticised because the governing Thursday, 19 September 1996 MAIN COMMITIEE 4843 party promised at the last election it would not do so. It is a tragedy, but it was a promise that had to be made at the time. However, if the Australian private sector is to provide the real GDP growth and jobs we require, it is absolutely imperative that this parliament-and I do not say this government or this opposition, I say this parliament-join together to take the lead of the Australian tax system out of the saddlebags of Australian industry. There is not a politician in this place who does not agree that the Australian tax system is a mess and a huge burden to Australian employers. I pointed out last night to the member for Corio( Mr O'Connor), with his huge responsibility to people in the car industry, that $700 to $800 is the cost, as estimated by Australia's Treasury, that feeds into the manufactured cost of every motor car made in Australia, because of the Australian tax system. We blame the workers for their lack of productivity, yet we never blame the Australian tax system, and it is probably the worse of the two. I think that Australian workers have lifted their productivity; the facts are there. But, while we are blaming the workers and denying them jobs, we sit in this place being too smart by half, using the tax system as a political tool when we should be joining together, every one of us, to put down a sensible reform package for each level of government: local, state and federal. I tell you what: we would create many brownie points with the Australian community if, on an area of such national importance, we got together and demonstrated bipartisanship. I think the last person to do it was a Labor person, Mr Curtin, when he invited Bob Menzieswho foolishly, as I remember, declined-to form a government of national interest to defend Australia during the war. Of course we should get together on these sorts of issues. It is too big for political pettiness. The Australian tax system is the worse. Australia is in a tax time warp, and the rest of the world is passing us by. Let me return to my written words and say that we should all be collectively ashamed of ourselves if we cannot join together to establish a workable solution for revenue raising in all three levels of government in our country. There is nothing wrong with, at that time, addressing the difficulties for certain groups of people, the poor and the disadvantaged, of any system. But let us get together and say, 'This is the best tax system; these are the difficulties it creates; let us address them in that circumstance.' Another urgent requirement is that interest rates fall by about two per cent, if the private sector is to fill the gap being created by the public sector. Such a fall in interest rates would have two benefits: reducing the direct cost of doing business and investing in the capital assets we need for real growth; and, of course, reducing the value of the Australian dollar. Mr Deputy Speaker, I have approached the opposition representative and I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard two graphs that show both the exports growth and economic growth that occur when the Australian dollar falls in value compared with foreign currencies. Leave granted. as they fall within the guidelines of the Speaker. The graphs read as follows-

Interest rates will fall only when governments stop borrowing money. Inflation need not rise with a lower exchange rate. The international price of the goods that come in means that they will cost more to import at a lower dollar value and, of course, that will improve the opportunity for Australian business to fill the gaps. The simple fact is that there is no such thing as an international price for a product that has been manufactured. The price is what the local market will bear. Of course, the performance of local industry has a lot to do with that. You can buy cars in various parts of the world, but they look awfully the same to me; yet they are substantially different in price because of local market conditions. But a lower dollar value is not the reason that we will get inflation. Inflation will rise if the trade union movement seeks to steal from future generations by claiming the benefits of economic growth that would result from lower exchange rates. The joke is that, if they try to force wages up-as they are trying to do now, more for political reasons than anything else-they will force inflation up. One of the most remarkable things that I have never been able to understand about trade union leaders is that, when they go out and get the workers a pay increase and, as a result of that we have inflation, that inflation means Mrs Jones pays more down at the supermarket; but, of course, the government has taken half the pay rise through taxation before Mrs Jones even gets the money to spend down at the supermarket. In fact, all the evidence shows that there has been a real drop in buying power as a result of some of these pay increases. It is plainly silly and it should not occur. There is another group of people in the community that should be considered in this regard-children. The debt processes of the last lO to 15 years and the forcing up of inflation are a charge against the children of this country. It is outrageous that that should even be considered. We must not have people rushing out for extra money the minute we start to get the economic growth we so desperately need to repay the debts of the last decade. I make the point that we can get the growth and we can put a million people back into work. It cannot be done artificially. It cannot be done by fiddling the books. Real jobs will only come with real growth, and governments have to recognise that. I still have business contacts through my family, and we have seen some of these make-job schemes. They are heart breaking. The people arriving to do the jobs know they are not going to stay. They have no interest in learning anything. There was no future in it. So what we are saying is, 'Let's make apprenticeships affordable.' An affordable apprenticeship for an employer is one that they will contract and keep. The reality is that, by taking away the cost of the days when the young people are not on the premises and thus creating some productivity for the employer, more employers will be prepared to take on young people. It is stupid to think, as is currently the law, that young people should be paid the same wages as old people. It is back to this king having no clothes argument. The reality is that when you get to that, the kids do not get a job. They do not get an apprenticeship. It is as simple as that. If we want to have skilled people so we do not have to import skilled welders from the Philippines-as occurred in my state recently-then we have to do it. I encourage everybody to get together on these issues. on behalf of the budget presented by the Treasurer ( Mr Costello). I believe it was a very responsible budget. It was, by its nature, a tough budget, but it was a budget that had to be tough. Many people around Australia understand that after the profligate years of Keating we had to do something to try and rein back the debt that was occurring in this country. I have heard many speakers on the other side talk about this being an unconscionable budget. They say there have been cuts in areas where people can least afford them and that this is a terrible government that has no compassion. They are ignoring the fact that many of them belonged to the government that ran up this enormous debt; a debt that grew from $30 billion to $180 billion during their term and a series of deficit budgets which could not continue. The last budget was brought down to bring in a surplus of more than $3 billion, and yet we found that at the end of the day, we had a deficit of more than $5 billion. That is total irresponsibility. Any company or any business that was running its affairs in such a way would be broke tomorrow morning. Australia is no different. We have to run our affairs responsibly. The members opposite who have been crying about the fact that certain areas have been cut, areas where people who are disadvantaged are not to receive the benefits that they received in the past, forget that if we continue to run deficit budgets such as that, if we continue to run up debt, then the very people they want to help most in the long-term are the people they will not be able to help. There are plenty of examples around the world of economies that have got out of control, where people have had to move in and take control of those economies. The very first thing that happens is that welfare is slashed. The people that all governments, all parties, all members of political parties want to help-the disadvantaged members of society---cannot be helped because we do not have the finances, we do not have the wherewithal to do it. It was put by the member for O'Connor( Mr Tuckey) that deficits have another effect. They certainly have an effect on interest rates. They undoubtedly have an effect on employment. I put to this House that, in fact, the deficit that we have run up over the last years has exported jobs from this country. The fact is that we do not have the savings in Australia for Australians to have shares in their own companies. The fact that these companies, because of the debt that has been run up, are being taken over by foreign companies is something that concerns Australians. The very basis of that is the fact that we have not had control of our finances. I keep on having people coming to me from my electorate-the electorate of Page, which is on the north coast of New South Wales-and saying, 'Don't resile from the job. Keep on with it, because we understand that we have to straighten this country out. We cannot leave a debt to our children and grandchildren and expect them to have to pay for our profligate ways.' I am sure that there are a number of people in Australia who share that view. I believe that the member for Oxley (Ms Hanson) touched on a lot of issues in the community which go deep into this budget and go deep into the areas that budgets are about in Australia, those of funding particular programs about which many Australians are very concerned. I have been concerned that there have been members of this House stand up and try to, in some ways, downplay what the member for Oxley had to say. In some instances,
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Causley (Page) 0.13 P.m.)
theText: It is a great pleasure to stand up in this House and reply4848 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 19 September 1996 I believe they have been trying to quieten her and deny her the right to speak in this place and bring forward her views. In many instances these days, unfortunately, in Australia we are not allowing freedom of speech. We are not allowing these views to be brought forward. If someone dares to say it, they are either 'discriminating' or they are 'vilifying' and they are howled down. I believe that the member for Oxley has every right to raise, in this parliament, the issues that she raised. Mr Ted Grace-Do you agree with her? What parts do you agree with? Do you agree with her on migrants or Aboriginals? prepared to listen, I will tell you. The Labor Party, of course, have failed, because they are the ones who have created these issues. The Labor Party have failed in these areas because, obviously, they have not addressed the problems that the society sees. When people say that there are a minority of people supporting the member for Oxley, I tum them to the poll done by Alan Jones, which showed that 98 per cent of the people in the community had these concerns. I am not saying that the concerns are legitimate. But I have to say this to you: because governments of different persuasions have been pandering to minority groups for some years now, the mainstream of Australia feels left out. They feel that they are being discriminated against. I think that is the issue that the member for Oxley has raised. It is a legitimate issue for this parliament to debate. If you look at those areas where the mainstream of Australia believe that they are discriminated against, you find we have to address it. We cannot hide it. We cannot slip it under the carpet and say, 'Look, it will go away.' It will fester and it will cause problems in this society that we cannot control if we do not address the issues that are involved. People will say it is discrimination and people will say it is vilification. I do not believe it is necessarily so. I do not say that there is not any discrimination in this country. In fact, I agree that there is. But the fact is that we must address these areas of concern. It is not just within the mainstream community in Australia. If you talk to the minority groups-if you talk to the rank and file Aboriginal people-they will say to you that money is being squandered and money is not getting to the grassroots where it is needed. The very people who need the support are not getting the money, even though we have spent millions of dollars on it. They are not getting the support that is necessary. It is something we must address. We just cannot push it away and say, 'That is discrimination. You should not talk about this.' I might also say-and it goes back to the discrimination argument and the Asian statements that were made by the member for Oxley-that the real concern in the community is not to do with Asians, but is to do with immigration. They are saying, 'Here are our children. They cannot get work in Australia, yet we are bringing people in from overseas.' We are saying that we have to bring people in from overseas because they have skills. Yet our young people do not have skills. I think this government has addressed that in some way in this budget. I think that you can go further, but there is no doubt in my mind that to give assistance to apprenticeships, where you are training people in long-term skills, is very important. I have had some concerns for some time now that the apprenticeship system has served its purpose. The old indentured apprenticeship system might have served its purpose. The world

speaker: Mr Causley
theText: If you listen carefully, you will hear what I have got to say. If you areThursday, 19 September 1996 MAIN COMMITTEE 4849 has changed, changed dramatically, and technology has caused that in many ways. Employers can no longer afford to have apprentices under the old system, particularly where they have to go away for quite some time on block release. That is why they are not taking on apprentices, that is why we have not got our young people trained. I think that this budget does something about that, that it gives some incentive to employers to take on apprentices and to see that they are trained. Those areas are very important and we must address them. The Labor government had a method of just pouring taxpayers' money into this. I do not say that all of their labour market programs were bad. In fact, there were a couple of programs that were pretty good but in many instances, because they were so determined to manipulate the unemployment figures, this money was entirely wasted. We saw a program on the north coast of New South Wales in the dying days of the Labor government where they threw $21 million at creating 1,750 jobs, which was ostensibly to try to save the two Labor members up there, the then member for Richmond and the then member for Page. But people saw through it. They saw that this was just a waste of their money. This is one of the attitudes that are in society today, that people are sick and tired of governments wasting taxpayers' money. I believe that this government was elected on some of that emotion. People were saying, 'We have had enough of this, we want a change, we want to get away from the systems that we have at the present time.' I believe that the member for Oxley tapped into this emotion. There is no doubt about that. This government, if it does not listen to the concerns of that great bulk of Australians out there, will go the same way as the Keating government because people believe that governments are elected to do something about the concerns that they see in their society. I want to get more specific about my electorate of Page on the north coast of New South Wales. I was delighted to see in the budget that the Minister for Transport and Regional Development ( Mr Sharp) had honoured a promise which probably emanated from the parliament of New South Wales where the coalition government there proposed a Motorway Pacific. It was a grand scheme for a divided highway between Brisbane and Sydney. We have an upgrade of the highway between Melbourne and Sydney, to a great extent completed at this stage, but the other great arterial road link in Australia is between Brisbane and Sydney. The Pacific Highway was a total mess 10 years ago until the New South Wales government and the Commonwealth government put substantial funds into it and upgraded it. However, it needs to be upgraded substantially if we are going to have a very good economic link between those two cities. I would like to say that this is a great start. We are going to have the sections from Coolongolook to Bulahdelah and from Chinderah to Billinudgel upgraded. However, there is a link in between that we need to continue on. We should not forget that this is a start on this particular link and we should continue on. There is a link in my electorate which goes from Harwood Island bridge on the Clarence River down nearly to Woolgoolga at what is called Dirty Creek Range. That is a link that needs to be put through as quickly as possible, otherwise you will have to go back to the old meandering highway, up through the valley, and that is just not good enough for a major link. While I am extremely delighted that the government has found the funds to upgrade these two sections I am saying not to forget that project because I believe it would probably equal the Snowy Mountains scheme in days gone past because it is an extremely important infrastructure program for Australia. 4850 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 19 September 1996 I understand also that the minister took note of another road which we call the Summerland Way which takes off from Grafton and wanders up to Casino and into Queensland behind the range, up through that area. For some time the Summerland Way has needed upgrading and I understand that the minister is talking to the New South Wales government at the present time-some positive talks, I am told-about getting an upgrading of that particular road. That area takes some of the heavy traffic away from the Pacific Highway where most of the population is. That route from Grafton through to the Queensland border, past Kyogle, will certainly alleviate some of that heavy traffic in that area and I commend the Minister for Transport and Regional Development for coming forward with those proposals. Small business was a big part of the government's election promise. I was listening to the member for Lalor( Mr Barry Jones). He was saying, 'How are we going to get all these jobs? Are you going to cut wages? Are you going to work at the lower end of the socioeconomic group? How are you going to do it?' I know the member for Lalor has been an eminent academic in his day but obviously he has never been in business, because that is where you generate the jobs. Jobs are generated in business. Unfortunately, I think, at the present time, of the wealth generating area of Australia, only about 11 per cent of Australians are employed in that particular sector. It is an area where we need to grow if we are going to get involved and if we are going to improve this economy. Obviously, small business is a very important part of that. I can tell you that from my discussions with small business, do not underestimate the effects of the anti-dismissal laws. People are absolutely terrified of them. Rightly or wrongly, they are absolutely terrified of them. When we have decisions in the courts over someone who was dismissed because they were taking money from the till and the courts let them off and say, 'Well, you didn't tell them not to', I think that is a very sad day for Australia. I believe that that is one rule that you should be taught as soon as you can talk-that you should not steal. I believe it is a law that was always taught in our community. For a court to come down with a decision such as that is absolutely abysmal. The small business community has been terrified by it. While this approach in the industrial relations laws is to modify it-it is not taking it away; it is modifying it-to remove the extremes, I think is a very good move in the right direction. The other area which has tended to be overlooked, particularly by the Labor Party when in government, is the fact that in small business all of the equity is in the business. Everything they own and everything they have worked for over years is in the business. If you are going to tax them in some way that does not allow them to enlarge that business, then you are inhibiting a very, very large sector of the Australian economy. That is what this is doing at the present time. This particular budget measure is saying that, if you want to enlarge your business, if you want to sell a business and go into a larger business, then we are not going to charge you tax on that. We are also going to allow you to retire with some of the assets that you have built up. We are not going to tax that because that is your superannuation, that is what you have worked for. Surely those are incentives that are worthwhile and would be supported from both sides of the political fence, because they are so important in our economy. I think both sides of politics agree that small business is very important in Australia and it is an area that must be helped. I noted that some of the opposition did raise the spectre of the ABC. Of course, coming from a rural electorate, I can assure you that I am very conscious of the ABC and some of the Thursday, 19 September 1996 MAIN COMMITTEE 4851 funding cuts that have been put forward. CanI say, though, that I believe the ABC over many years have not addressed inefficiencies, have not addressed their management structure, have not really closely looked at some of their programming. I believe that there are savings to be found. If you look at many of the major companies in Australia over the last 10 years, they have had some soul searching to do themselves. They have looked very closely at the management structures; they have looked very closely at their costs to see whether they could prune them and get profit back, and many of them have. I think the ABC is in the same position. CanI say to you, though, that I am certainly speaking out loudly on behalf of regional news and regional programs. I think that that is what the ABC was based on in the first place-to get radio out across Australia. I do not think that role has changed, quite frankly; it is a core role. I would be extremely disappointed if management did not see the need to continue that particular core element in the ABC. I would speak out strongly against it if, in fact, that were the case. In the little time. I have left, I would like to touch on the point that I probably came into politics about 12 years ago and that is forestry. I am very concerned at the present time about the fact that the New South Wales Labor government is using the national forest policy as a means to close down small country communities. I do not believe that the policies that were put in place by the federal government, and that includes the previous government, were meant to be used in such away. I know that there is a very important need to have comprehensive and adequate reserves of forest types across Australia, but unfortunately we see that extremists take this to a further point which really does undermine industry and production and employment. Unfortunately, we have elements of the New South Wales Labor government at the present time who are trying to use this particular excuse to further their green agenda. I know I have the support of the members of the Labor Party in New South Wales. I hope I have enough support because I have spoken to a few in recent days. I call on them to look very carefully at the spurious arguments that are being advanced in this particular debate. There is far too much dishonesty in the debate. If we look at the scientific facts, it is not supported by scientific fact but it can have very detrimental effects on small communities. It can have very detrimental effects on the economies of rural areas and very detrimental effects on the economy of Australia. I ask that anyone in this parliament who has influence talk to colleagues in the other states because this is a very important issue. Mr Deputy Speaker, thank you very much for giving me the opportunity to address this budget. I believe that it is a very responsible budget. I believe it will set the foundations for a very strong economic return in Australia. Debate (on motion by Mr Ted Grace) adjourned.
